Posts.Content: May 22, 2009 03:52PM bonnid wrote: Jayne,  yes the picture is from the survivors lap.  I thought I'd be real slow walking around the park but surprisingly I kept up with everyone or they were just keeping pace with my slow walk - I was in the front of the pack.  You can see the photos my daughter took of the walk at http://picasaweb.google.com/bonnid/RelayForLife2009?feat=directlink  Brahna

Posts.Content: May 8, 2009 11:52AM bonnid wrote: Jayne and MI_Runner -- Hope your surgery goes well.  Luckily, I think, I don't have to be there as early as you do.  Surgery is scheduled for 12 so I don't need to be at the outpatient surgery center  until 10.  And I have a one night stay in the hospital.  I think it's starting to hit me now.  I'm now starting to get a little bit nervous.  When I get engrossed in work, I don't have to think about it so I guess it's good that I'm working through today. The one thing that has bothered me throughout is that no one in the medical offices is telling me what to expect afterwards or what I will need to have with me.  When I went for my lumpectomy, I was wearing a tank top and no bra.  After surgery, the nurse asked where was my bra and the written instructions told me that I needed to wear one 24 hours for a few days after surgery.  So this time I've been proactive asking what I need.  Hopefully, I haven't missed anything!
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 11, 2009 07:39AM bonnid wrote: Jayne, Kimberly, MI_Runner: I hope you all had a wonderful mother's day.  As I prepare to join you in our journey today, I am sending you hugs.  I hope all has gone well with your surgeries.  Jayne: as I went to bed last night, I was sending my thoughts were with you as I believe you were just entering this stop on our journey together.

Posts.Content: May 15, 2009 11:57AM bonnid wrote: Oh Jayne - you are so lucky to have the drains removed so soon.  I don't get mine removed until Tuesday when I see my ps.  Saw my bs yesterday so he could change the dressing. He had just received my path report - there were 14 lymph nodes that were in the pad they removed.  One had micrometasasis. So that's a total of 2 out of 17.  Not sure what that's going to mean for future treatment but I should find out next week when I see my oncologist. Is anyone experiencing numbness under the arm and in the upper arm?  I went to put on deodorant and it felt so weird - no sensation that I was rolling it on.

But then I'll get a recommendation for someone close by.  My plan is to know as much as I can about my treatment/options prior to mx.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 04:42PM bonnid wrote: MilleD - I understand what you mean.  When they told me that I'm only going to have to stay overnight I couldn't believe it.  I've seen posts where some women have stayed several nights in the hospital. I haven't yet reached the point of being anxious -- maybe that will come next weekend.  My surgery is the 11th. MI_Runner - I have not been focusing so much on the surgery as what is happening afterwards.  Originally, my bs told me that I'd see an oncologist after the lumpectomy I had on March 27th - well I went along with that.  But afterwards, when I found out I'd have to have more surgery I decided that I had to start finding out everything I could and got myself to see a ps and oncologist.  And I've been reading up on what the other women have said.  I'd take each day at a time and learn as much as you can.  Talk to the people in the doctor's offices.  I've found they're very helpful.  Good luck with your meeting tomorrow.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 12:27PM bonnid wrote: Hi everyone, Just checking in.  Surgery went well.  I'm not in as much pain as I had imagined.  It's more like discomfort - but I'm taking those pain pills to keep it that way.  I had a bit of nausea after the surgery and even Monday nite when I was in the hospital after the recovery room.  I got through that - I had the anesthesiologist looking out for me as I had a terrible bout of nausea and throwing up after my lumpectomy.  I don't think it was quite as bad this time.  Surprisingly the instructions I was given say that it's ok to drive when I feel responsible and it's okay to lift 10-15 lbs.  Jayne, Kimberly - great to hear that you got through surgery okay

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 05:50PM bonnid wrote: Pattipig - I had my mx same day as you on May 11.  That Sat was our Relay for Life.  I had made it my goal to walk the survivors lap at the start of the relay.  I chose an XL t-shirt and miraculously was able to get it on - I think because it was so big.  I had 2 layers under it - my camisole and button up shirt.  No one could tell.  Don't let it bother you.  You'll find that many of the survivors also went through mx and they certainly won't be judging what you look like.  They'll be encouraging and helpful. And I don't think that anyone there will be consiously looking at your chest. Actually most of the others will be wrapped up in their team enthusiasm.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 20, 2009 11:52AM bonnid wrote: I saw my ps yesterday.  I STILL have the drain.  He won't take it out until it's collecting a teaspoon or less - something like 15-20cc or less.  What a bummer.  But he did take off the dressing and left me with some bandages.  I got my first look.  My husband thought I'd freak out or something but I just took it in stride.  What more can I do?  What is.. is!   I could have ended up in a much worse predicament. It's ironic that when I emptied the drain it looked as if it was 20cc.  The cup they gave me has the markings starting at 30cc.  So I took a teaspoon of water, put it into the cup and then marked it.  Now tonite I'll know for sure.  If that's the case, my husband knows what to do to remove the drain. And then it's just a 24 hour wait before I can finally shower again.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 10:35PM bonnid wrote: Pattipig - I am so glad you did the Survivors walk. It sounds like your attitude changed completely about doing it. I'm proud of you. Debbie - I can't address facial hair in relation to chemo as I haven't started chemo yet. But I can address it generally as I have had it since I was an older teenager. I have had it removed through electrolysis but it didn't last for me. I think because I couldn't handle a high current. I did use electrolysis to remove the hairs on that were centered below my belly button - I was belly dancing at the time and didn't want those hairs showing. I still have facial hair and have been cutting it when it begins to show. I stopped going for electrolysis as I couldn't afford it at the time. I pretty much lost all the hairs on my legs when I went through menopause. I have recently thought about lasar hair removal but have put that thought aside until I see what happens after my chemo. I am also concerned about if and how much facial hair I will end up with after chemo. I am planning to do the lasar removal if I end up with significant facial hair. BTW, I got a referral from my dermatologist.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 25, 2009 11:52AM bonnid wrote: Don.. When I had my lumpectemy they also did the sentinal node removal.  Apparently the sentinal node was buried below two other lymph nodes which were removed first.  My bs said that he took out the first node and when he put the counter on it alone there was no reaction and the same with the second node.  The third one he took out caused the counter to react.   Just before the anesthesia put me out entirely, I heard the noise from the counter. (geiger counter is what I think of) So when they're doing the sentinal node removal it depends on where the node is in relation to the other nodes as far as how many get removed. In my case, I think it was a good thing because the path report showed micrometasis in one of those extra lymph nodes and nothing in the sentinal. Brahna

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 07:51AM bonnid wrote: Getting ready to go for my first treatment this morning.  I ordered a wig yesterday because I didn't want to have to worry about it later when I might not be feeling so well.  I'm staying optomistic.  I am not expecting to get sick/nauseous even though I know most do and most likely will.  I still have too many things to accomplish.  Time will tell. . . .
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2009 11:27PM bonnid wrote: Hi everyone.  Had my first (of TCx4)  treatment today.   We were there for close to six hours due to all the education that they gave us.  It was a lot to absorb.  I'm glad that I taped/recorded what they told me because not all of it is written.  I haven't had any reactions so far. The infusions went smoothly.  I have drunk a ton of water today and am always having to go to the bathroom - that's the one thing I hate.  I already have to go so much.  I would hope that by now the chemicals are flushed out of my system.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 10:26PM bonnid wrote: Bettina - maybe it's the June 4th karma.  My first chemo was also June 4th and I have had no SE of any consequences.  Mainly I get tired often.  I went back to work on June 8th but I'm working half time which helps out with the tiredness. Tonight I'm finding that when I run my hands through my hair,  my scalp hurts the way it hurts when you change your part or pull it in another direction.  I'm guessing that it's the start of my hair coming out. Anyone having the same kind of symptom? Brahna
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 06:51PM bonnid wrote: I cut my hair almost 2 weeks ago.  It was coming out if I gently pulled it.  Now it's not easily coming out and it sticks into my head.  I've taken to using a lint roller.  That's helping but I feel weird afterwards so I have to hop in the shower.  Mostly I wear my wig to work and have a great time.  Those people that hadn't heard about this journey complement me on my new hairdo.  I know that once my hair grows in and I can color it, it's going to be a color similar to my wig.  I do enjoy wearing scarves and hats.  I mentioned that to one of my co-workers.  He said I should just come in wearing whatever makes me comfortable.  Maybe one of these days I'lll do that.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 05:34PM bonnid wrote: Hi everyone.  I had my 2nd TC chemo on Thursday.  I was feeling fantastic. I left and went to have 'desert' with my daughters and my dear friend Tari.  Afterwards, my daughter Deborah asked if I wanted to go clothing shopping - yes I did, but I didn't go as I knew I needed to rest  I woke up yesterday with a fever of 101.  It was time to take the cipro that I had been instructed to take if I had fever over 100.5.  We had to be at my onc's office that morning for my neulasta shot.  Well, turns out my blood pressure was very low.  I apparently was dehydrated.  I don't know how that happened as I was drinking a lot of water, etc.  Anyway, I ended up getting rehydrated by IV for most of the day.  Afterwards, Tom and I went to Souplantation -- no salad for me.  And then last nite, I felt more naseous than I have in the past.  I ended up going through all the anti- nausea regime - 2 pills and a suppository.  Went to sleep and woke up feeling a little better. This morning Deborah took me to my appt with Dr; Wang, my accupuncturist.  I walked out feeling so much better.   She works miracles.  I appologize for not commenting on the posts.  I have been having a hard time concentrating on reading them and keeping up with everyone. Perhaps, I'll be up to reading them again soon.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 09:44PM bonnid wrote: Hi all, Today I had my 3rd tx.  All went okay.  We'll see how I react in the next couple of days.  Because I had nausea last time and ended up dehydrated, they increased one of my anti nausea meds and added another one.   I arrived at 9:45 am and wasn't done until 3pm. -  an all day procedure. So far, so good - no adverse reactions.  Brahna
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 09:24AM - edited Aug 15, 2009 09:25AM by bonnid I've not posted in quite a while. Tried to catch up on what's happened with everyone but I can't remember it all - is that Chemo Brain. I know I blame alot on my chemo brain whether true or not. But hey, it's a good excuse I can use right now. Zuzee - I'm going to look you up on facebook. Had my last T/C tx last Thursday (Aug 6th)! So happy. I was gathering all my stuff after the treatment, turned around and found my onc and most of her staff standing there. They SANG me a congratulations song and she (my onc) gave me a bottle of sparkly - Martinelli's. Then the rest of the staff left and those, including the doctor,  who had been involved in my treatment stayed to give me big hugs. It was all so touching. Should have had my hubby take a photo but didn't think of it until after we walked out. Went back the next day for Neulasta shot. last one Yeah! It seems that unlike a lot of you, I have gotten through it all with very little SE. I had one bout of dehydration. That's when they added Emend to my treatment - for the last 2 rounds. No signs of nausea after that. I go to work (half-time) and everyone is amazed at how well I'm doing. And so am I. I blame it on my ancillary helpers: My dentist gave me a mouth rinse to use every night: Pro-Den Rx PerioCheck. My (nutritional) chiropractor gave me a list of food supplements to take (they're sold only in practitioner's offices) - the brand name is Standard Process. I'm not always faithful but I will say that when I started this journey I was faithful in taking them. And then there's Dr. Wang - the most amazing Accupuncturist & Traditiional Chinese Medicine doctor. She's so sweet and loving and cares so much about her patients. Without all of these people, I don't think that I would be doing as well as I have been. Oh and another thing that I have done/ am doing is no black (except my shoes). I have been wearing bright colors all summer. I have not thought about what might have been only that all is well right now and that's the way it's going to stay. And then I surprise everyone at work. They never know which me they'll see - blond, brunette, head scarf, cute cap. It makes for an interesting day and conversation. Hopefully this info will be helpful to someone. I had my last fill 2 days before my last chemo. The end is in sight. If I get my onc's blessing, I will have my exchange surgery Sept 30th exactly one week before my 65th birthday. I am so looking forward to my birthday!!!! Oh and last Sunday - tx4-d4 - was our anniversary and we went to the circus! I wanted to be playful.  ............   Brahna
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2009 05:08PM bonnid wrote: Lynn - Good Luck on your first day back at school. I hope you don't have any problems with the kids. Anna - I have a cough that won't go away.  Seems to get worse later in the day.  My accupuncturist is working to get rid of it for me.  In the meantime, I get 'cough drops' from her that do a wonderous job of keeping the cough at bay.  I just put it in my mouth and let it sit in my cheek - no cough.

Hope everyone is doing okay today with no major side effects. Brahna
